comments.content: This is all assuming the IP is just incorrect in the diagram,

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct. I labbed this up, from R4's perspective, the routes from router 5.5.5.5 only have 65505 in the AS-Path, the as-path filtering is processed before the local AS (65504) is appended to the AS-Path.

So A works exactly as depicted.

Something is wrong in the answers
'A' works, but it should be the IP address of R1
'B' would work with out direction and the IP of R1

comments.content: DUsoo is right, there is some mix ups here. The configuration of A looks correct if it was R1.

discussion.content:
Output is from R1 --> and network 5.5.5.5 has next hop IP 10.0.23.3 so "A" can not be the correct one. R4 has interface IP 10.0.23.3 and not R1.

R4#router bgp 65504 -
neighbor 10.0.23.3 remote-as 65501 --> this is not correct neighbor IP!

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. There is a BGP traffic path issue between Customer-1 and Customer-2. Users from Customer-2 have reported file transfer issues. High utilization on the path between both customers causes many packet drops. Which configuration resolves the issue?

choices.C:
R1#neighbor 10.0.23.3 route-map LOCAL-PREF-150 out
route-map LOCAL-PREF-150
set local-preference 150
choices.D:
R1#neighbor 10.0.24.4 route-map LOCAL-PREF-150 in
route-map LOCAL-PREF-150
set local-preference 150
ip prefix-list 5-5-5-S seq 5 permit 5.5.5.5/32
route-map LOCAL-PREF-150 permit 10
match ip address prefix-list 5-S-5-5
set local-preference 150
choices.A:
R4#router bgp 65504 -
neighbor 10.0.23.3 remote-as 65501
neighbor 10.0.23.3 filter-list 1 out
ip as-path access-list 1 deny ^65505$
ip as-path access-list 1 permit .*
choices.B:
R4#router bgp 65504 -
address-family ipv4 unicast
neighbor 10.0.23.3 remote-as 65501
neighbor 10.0.23.3 activate
neighbor 10.0.23.3 route-map PREPEND in
exit-address-family
exit
route-map PREPEND permit 10
set as-path prepend 65506 65507

R3# configure terminal -
R3(config)# ip multicast-routing
R3(config)# interface gigabitethernet 1/0/0
R3(config-if)# ip pim sparse-mode
R3(config-if)# ip igmp version 3
R3(config)# interface gigabitethernet 1/0/1
R3(config-if)# ip pim sparse-mode
R3(config-if)# ip igmp version 3
R3(config-if)# ip pim ssm default
choices.A:
R3# configure terminal -
R3(config)# no ip pim ssm default
R3(config)# interface gigabitethernet 1/0/0
R3(config-if)# ip pim sparse-mode
R3(config-if)# ip igmp version 3
R3(config-if)# ip pim ssm default
R3(config)# interface gigabitethernet 1/0/1
R3(config-if)# ip pim sparse-mode
R3(config-if)# ip igmp version 3
R3(config-if)# ip pim ssm default
choices.C:
R3(config)# interface gigabitethernet 1/0/0
R3(config-if)# ip pim sparse-mode
R3(config-if)# ip igmp version 3
R3(config)# interface gigabitethernet 1/0/1
R3(config-if)# ip pim sparse-mode
R3(config-if)# ip igmp version 3
choices.D:
R3(config)# interface gigabitethernet 1/0/0
R3(config-if)# ip pim sparse-mode
R3(config)# interface gigabitethernet 1/0/1
R3(config-if)# ip pim sparse-mode
R3(config-if)# ip igmp version 3

comments.content: Sorry, IGMP3 needed only on the interface where the receivers are

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
IGMP needed only on the interface where the receivers are

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A network engineer is configuring router R3 to handle multicast streams, but Host-2 cannot send subscription messages to the IPTV source. Which configuration must the engineer apply to router R3 so it passes the IPTV stream to Host-2?
What is the purpose of ACL type prefix set entries in RPL prefix sets?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct

choices.B: They hold IPv4 or IPv6 prefixes that do not match specifications.
choices.D: They hold IPv4 prefixes that do not match specifications.
choices.C: They hold IPv4 or IPv6 prefix match specifications.
choices.A: They hold IPv6 prefix match specifications.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I think the keys to this question are in:
- Routers D and E are directly connected iBGP peers. 
 - Router F is not an iBGP peer of routers D and E.
If BGP client-to-client reflection is disabled, routers D and E will continue to exchange information since they are directly connected. Router F is not, but it is not and iBGP peer to D and E. There is a circle there, but it doesn't say it is the same AS. I think B is the best option here.

comments.content: Looking closer, 10.10.10.1 is not an eBGP peer, and next-hop-self doesn't apply to reflected routes so Im not sure of an answer here

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Not the best written question but the fact that Router C is a gateway to an eBGP peer means it should use next-hop-self for all the iBGP routers so I pick answer D

This document explains router reflectors nicely

https://www.ciscolive.com/c/dam/r/ciscolive/emea/docs/2020/pdf/R6BGArNQ/TECRST-1310.pdf#xd_co_f=MDkyZDAyMmUtN2RlMS00ZjIzLTk2ZDMtNzMwN2FkZTMyMzQx~

Is here any correct answer???

A) Remove the route-reflector configuration on router RR2 - no, we do not have full-mesh 
B) Disable BGP client-to-client reflection - we do not have full-mesh
C) Enable next-hop-self for BGP peering on router D - next-hop is changed only if the route is received from eBGP
D) Enable next-hop-self for BGP peering on router C. - next-hop-self command on the route reflector will modify next hop attributes only for routes that are learned from eBGP peers

comments.content: No DUsoo, I also don't see any correct answer to this.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. While troubleshooting a networking issue, an engineer identified a suboptimal communication issue on route reflector RR2. In the current environment:
• Router A is a non-route-reflector client for RR1 and RR2.
• Routers D and E are directly connected iBGP peers.
• Router F is not an iBGP peer of routers D and E.

Which action resolves the issue?

choices.D: Enable next-hop-self for BGP peering on router C.
choices.A: Remove the route-reflector configuration on router RR2.
choices.C: Enable next-hop-self for BGP peering on router D.
choices.B: Disable BGP client-to-client reflection on router RR2.
Configure all routers to reside in the same area.
choices.D: Configure R3 as a Level 1 /Level 2 router.
choices.A: Configure R5 in the same area as R1.
choices.C: Configure R1 and R5 as Level 1/Level 2 routers.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Yes, B is correct
